metadata.official_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

rankings.market_position: Leading Public STEM Research University with High ROI
rankings.executive_summary: Missouri University of Science and Technology is a STEM-focused public research university consistently recognized for its strong engineering programs and high return on investment for graduates. It is ranked among the top national universities and is noted for career placement and salary impact.
rankings.admissions_philosophy: Holistic review emphasizing academic preparedness and interest in STEM fields

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Missouri University of Science and Technology fosters a close-knit and supportive social environment with a collaborative atmosphere. Students often describe the community as friendly and helpful, with many opportunities for study groups and involvement in over 200 student organizations. While the academic rigor in STEM fields is high, the campus mood can be characterized as "nerdy" with a strong emphasis on innovation and problem-solving. Some reviews indicate a desire for more diversity and on-campus activities outside of academics and Greek life.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: The campus of Missouri University of Science and Technology is of medium size and located in Rolla, Missouri, which is described as a small college town with a lively atmosphere. This likely contributes to easy navigation around campus and the surrounding community.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Missouri University of Science and Technology provides strong undergraduate research opportunities, with a significant percentage of students, particularly in biological sciences, participating in research. Students are encouraged to publish and present their work at regional and national conferences. The university offers various programs to facilitate research, including Opportunities for Undergraduate Research Experiences (OURE), which provides stipends, and the First Year Research Experience (FYRE), which pairs students with faculty mentors and industry professionals. Undergraduates can also gain experience through research assistant roles, credit-bearing research courses, employment in labs, and participation in interdisciplinary design teams like iGEM. The university hosts an Undergraduate Research Conference and a Research Day at the Capitol to showcase student work. Missouri S&T has a strong career focus, especially for engineering students, with high job placement rates and one of the largest career fairs in the Midwest. The curriculum emphasizes research-based projects, internships, and experiential learning, preparing students for careers in STEM and other fields.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Missouri S&T is a moderately selective institution with acceptance rates generally ranging from 72.5% to 84%, indicating that strong academic performance and a well-rounded application are important for admission.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should aim for a GPA above the average of 3.79 and competitive standardized test scores (SAT 1220-1400 or ACT 25-31) to be strong candidates. Highlighting rigorous coursework, such as AP or IB classes, can further strengthen an application.

analyst_takeaways.insight: The university boasts a strong reputation in engineering and STEM fields, with a hands-on approach, numerous design teams, and a high research designation from the Carnegie Foundation.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Prospective students, particularly those interested in engineering and STEM, should emphasize any practical experience, participation in science fairs, robotics clubs, or other relevant extracurricular activities in their applications. Expressing a clear interest in research or specific engineering disciplines can also be beneficial.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Missouri S&T offers excellent career outcomes, with graduates reporting high starting salaries (average $72,600) and a high likelihood of job placement or graduate school admission due to robust career fairs and strong industry connections.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should highlight their career aspirations and any internships, co-ops, or leadership roles that demonstrate their readiness for professional environments. Connecting their academic interests to specific career paths can show alignment with the university's strong focus on post-graduation success.

current_status.test_policy_details: Missouri University of Science and Technology is test-optional, allowing students to choose whether or not to submit standardized test scores (SAT/ACT). The university permits self-reporting of scores and allows superscoring for undergraduate admissions. While not strictly required, submitting strong scores is recommended and can enhance an applicant's chances.
current_status.notes: Data for the 2024 application year. This rate is lower than the general university acceptance rate.
current_status.acceptance_rate_notes: Missouri University of Science and Technology is a public university. While an overall acceptance rate of approximately 72.5% to 73% is widely reported, and a domestic vs. international breakdown (82.7% domestic, 51.3% international) was found, specific in-state and out-of-state (for US residents) acceptance rates are not explicitly available in the search results.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Data corresponds to the Fall 2021 entering class (CDS 2020-2021 academic year).
Data corresponds to the Fall 2022 entering class (CDS 2021-2022 academic year).
A groundbreaking ceremony for the new Welcome Center occurred on April 20, 2023. Data corresponds to the Fall 2023 entering class (CDS 2022-2023 academic year).

The new Welcome Center's construction was expected to be completed in Fall 2024, with a beam-signing ceremony on October 25, 2024. Data corresponds to the Fall 2024 entering class (CDS 2023-2024 academic year).

Missouri S&T achieved Carnegie R1 classification (Very High Research Activity) in 2025, with an official announcement on February 13, 2025. An EF-2 tornado struck Rolla on March 14, 2025, impacting the community. The dedication ceremony for the new Welcome Center is scheduled for October 3, 2025. Data corresponds to the Fall 2025 entering class (CDS 2024-2025 academic year).

gpa.notes: The average weighted GPA for admitted students is 3.81. The middle 50% for weighted GPA is 3.60-4.00, and for unweighted GPA is 2.50-3.50. Most incoming freshmen graduate in the top quarter of their high school class.

demographics.notes: Information for first-generation and legacy student percentages is typically found in the Common Data Set (CDS) documents. While Missouri University of Science and Technology makes its CDS available, direct access to the content of these documents to extract the specific percentages was not possible through the search function.

colleges.name: College of Engineering and Computing
colleges.housing_profile: Standard university housing (traditional, suite, and apartment-style dorms like Thomas Jefferson Hall, Residential Commons, University Commons, Miner Village, Rolla Suites). Students may also participate in Living Learning Communities such as the Honors Community (Residential Commons) or Change Makers Community (Residential Commons) to connect with like-minded, high-achieving peers. These residences offer furnished rooms, study spaces, lounges, and communal facilities like laundry and computer labs.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers with a strong aptitude for mathematics and science, driven to design and build. These students are highly dedicated to rigorous academic programs, particularly in engineering and computing fields, and are eager for hands-on experience through design teams and real-world projects. They are career-focused and value a supportive, collaborative academic environment.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strongly recommended for students with a solid STEM background who are prepared for a challenging curriculum and aspire to careers in diverse engineering or computing disciplines. Applicants should be eager to engage in extensive hands-on learning, participate in design teams, and leverage the university's strong industry connections and career placement services.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering

Must take the Fundamentals of Engineering Examination prior to graduation.

COMP SCI 1570 Introduction To C++ Programming (3) or equivalent programming elective

Must take the Fundamentals of Engineering Examination prior to graduation.

colleges.name: College of Arts, Sciences, and Education
colleges.housing_profile: Standard university housing (traditional, suite, and apartment-style dorms like Thomas Jefferson Hall, Residential Commons, University Commons, Miner Village, Rolla Suites). Students may also opt for Living Learning Communities such as the Performing Arts Community (University Commons), Change Makers Community (Residential Commons), or future communities like MiND Collective, Future of Health, Pickaxe Pioneers, and Tabletop Guild, which cater to diverse interests and provide enhanced residential support and programming. All rooms are furnished and offer access to study rooms, lounges, laundry, and sometimes computer learning centers and game rooms.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious and interdisciplinary thinkers who want to make a real-world impact. They are interested in a broad education spanning traditional liberal arts, humanities, natural and physical sciences, and education, often within a technological context. They seek experiential learning, research opportunities, and value critical thinking, creative expression, and collaboration.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a well-rounded education with a strong foundation in liberal arts and sciences, but who also appreciate a STEM-focused university environment. It suits those looking for versatile programs that offer hands-on learning, research opportunities, and pathways to diverse careers or advanced studies, including accelerated pharmacy programs or multidisciplinary global engineering.

majors.name: Biological Sciences
majors.special_requirements: A minimum grade of 'C' is required for each Biological Science course used to fulfill the B.S. degree requirements.

core_courses: BIO SCI 1201 Biological Sciences Freshman Seminar (1)
BIO SCI 1113 General Biology (3) or BIO SCI 1213 Principles of Biology (3)
electives: BIO SCI 2252 Vegetation of the Ozarks (2)

majors.notes: Minimum of 120 credit hours for the B.S. degree. A minimum grade of 'C' is required for each Biological Science course. Data source: Missouri S&T 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog

core_courses: PSYCH 4410 Neuroscience (3) or PSYCH 4411 Sensation and Perception (3)

majors.notes: Minimum of 120 credit hours for the B.S. degree. Data source: Missouri S&T 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog

colleges.name: Kummer College of Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and Economic Development
colleges.housing_profile: Standard university housing (traditional, suite, and apartment-style dorms like Thomas Jefferson Hall, Residential Commons, University Commons, Miner Village, Rolla Suites). Specific Living Learning Communities might be relevant for students interested in leadership or entrepreneurial pursuits, such as the Change Makers Community (Residential Commons) or potentially the Honors Community. These facilities provide furnished rooms, study areas, and communal amenities.
colleges.student_archetype: Innovative and entrepreneurial individuals who aim to translate scientific and technological discoveries into real-world solutions. They are driven by a desire to understand business, management, and economic development in a technology-driven world. These students possess leadership, communication, and decision-making skills, with a collaborative mindset and intellectual curiosity.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students passionate about the intersection of technology, business, and innovation. This college is a strong fit for those looking to develop entrepreneurial skills, engage in interdisciplinary research with industry connections, and prepare for leadership roles in various sectors, including business, management systems, information science, and economics. Opportunities like the Kummer Innovation and Entrepreneurship Doctoral Fellows program are particularly suited for those pursuing advanced research with a commercialization mindset.

majors.name: Business and Management Systems
majors.special_requirements: A minimum grade of 'C' is required in all core Business and Management Systems courses.

MKT 5310 Digital Marketing and Promotion (3) or BUS 5150 Customer Focus and Satisfaction (3)
STAT 3111 Statistical tools for Decision Making (3) or STAT 1115 Statistics for Social Sciences (3)

application_deadlines.notes: For Fall 2026 admission. This is the priority deadline for scholarship consideration.
For Fall 2026 admission. This is the final deadline for scholarship consideration.
For Fall 2026 admission. Recommended application deadline for the fall semester.

general_requirements: Personal statement/essay (optional for general admission, required for some scholarships/programs)

program_specific_requirements.details: Two short answer essays are required, especially for test-optional applicants. These essays address extracurricular activities and how the applicant will contribute to the Missouri S&T community.

program_specific_requirements.target_program: Music (Wind Symphony, Symphony Orchestra - Winds and Percussion)
program_specific_requirements.details: Auditions are required to perform with the Wind Symphony or Symphony Orchestra (winds and percussion) in the spring semester. Audition sign-up sheets are placed outside the band room (137 Castleman Hall). Contact Dr. Samson (samsondw@mst.edu) for questions. Auditions are not required for Wind Symphony in the fall semester or for Symphonic Band.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: The test-optional review process for freshman applicants includes a committee review that considers extracurricular activities and how the student will contribute to the Missouri S&T community. They offer specific scholarships for first-generation students (Trailblazer Scholarship) and descendants of alumni (Alumni Heritage Scholarship)

essay_details.required: Two short answer essays are required, especially for test-optional applicants. These essays address extracurricular activities and how the applicant will contribute to the Missouri S&T community.
tips: Address the prompt immediately and concisely, avoiding unnecessary meandering.
Show, don't tell: use concrete examples and vivid descriptions to illustrate your experiences and qualities rather than making broad claims.
Avoid clich√©s; strive for uniqueness in your writing to help you stand out.
Connect your experiences and aspirations explicitly to Missouri S&T's values, specific programs, or how you will contribute to their community.
Seek feedback and revise multiple times to ensure clarity, conciseness, and that all aspects of the prompt are fully answered.

major_selection_tactics: Apply to less competitive majors if not set on highly popular engineering or computer science fields. Missouri S&T is primarily known for its engineering and STEM programs. Popular majors include Mechanical Engineering, Information Science, Civil Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Aerospace Engineering, and Computer Science. If a student's academic profile is strong but they are concerned about the intense competition in these highly sought-after disciplines, exploring other strong STEM-related fields, or programs within the College of Arts, Sciences, and Business, might be a strategic approach.

Consider an undeclared option within a broader college. Missouri S&T offers degrees within the College of Arts, Sciences, and Business, in addition to the College of Engineering and Computing. While not explicitly detailed for admissions, applying undeclared within a broader college could offer more flexibility and potentially a different entry path than direct admission to an impacted engineering program. Once admitted, academic advisors can assist students in exploring and planning their degree paths.

Research the demand and typical profile for specific majors. Although major-specific acceptance rates are not readily available, understanding which majors are most popular can provide insight into potential competitiveness. Mechanical Engineering, General Computer & Information Sciences, and Civil Engineering consistently show high numbers of graduates, indicating their popularity and likely higher applicant pools. Applicants can gauge the potential demand for their intended major by reviewing such data and aligning their choice with their academic strengths and aspirations.
college_ranking_tactics: Invest in Robust Career Services and Experiential Learning: A key factor in Missouri S&T's strong rankings is its graduates' high starting salaries, excellent career placement, and extensive internship opportunities. A strategy to bolster rankings would involve continuously enhancing career services, fostering strong employer relationships, facilitating numerous paid co-op and internship experiences, and emphasizing hands-on learning across all colleges and departments.

Focus on Student Outcomes and Value Proposition: Rankings often consider return on investment (ROI), which includes factors like low student debt and the time it takes for graduates to earn back their education costs. A strategy should prioritize keeping tuition and living expenses manageable, offering competitive financial aid, and demonstrating the clear economic benefit of a degree from Missouri S&T's colleges. This also ties into strong graduation and retention rates.

Cultivate Academic Rigor and Student Support: Missouri S&T is recognized for its rigorous academic programs, especially in STEM fields. Maintaining high academic standards, coupled with supportive learning environments like small class sizes and accessible professors, helps ensure student success, which in turn positively impacts retention and graduation rates. Expanding resources such as tutoring and academic advising within each college further supports student achievement.

Showcase Specialized Program Excellence: Missouri S&T's engineering and STEM programs frequently receive high marks, with specific programs like Civil Engineering and Environmental/Environmental Health Engineering ranking in the top 50. A strategy involves actively promoting and investing in areas of distinct academic strength within its colleges, demonstrating leadership in specific fields, and highlighting unique research opportunities and faculty expertise in those areas.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: alternate_major_strategy: Missouri S&T's undergraduate application for first-time freshmen asks applicants to 'Select the major you wish to pursue' under 'Area of Study'. It advises against selecting 'Undecided or Undecided Engineering' for international students, implying a single major selection at the application stage. Therefore, rather than listing a separate alternate major on the initial application, a strategic approach would involve choosing an initial major that aligns with a student's interests and abilities, especially if their primary interest is in a highly competitive field like certain engineering disciplines. If the primary desired major is highly competitive, students might consider applying directly to a less competitive but related major that still genuinely interests them, with the intention of pursuing an internal transfer later if successful in their studies. General advice for selecting a backup major suggests choosing one within a different college or a less impacted STEM field (like math or a related science) if aiming for a competitive engineering program.; internal_transfer_difficulty: Internal transfer for majors, particularly within engineering and science departments at Missouri S&T, can be competitive. While the term 'impacted majors' isn't explicitly used, these departments generally reserve the right to enforce more stringent cumulative GPA requirements for internal transfer applications than the university's general minimum. Undergraduate students wishing to change majors must submit an application with the Office of the Registrar, and the receiving department must approve the change, often placing academic conditions upon the application. Consulting with an academic advisor is essential to understand how a major change might impact academic progress, course requirements, and graduation timeline.

financials.notes: Missouri University of Science and Technology attempts to fill financial needs to the extent funds are available. The 'Solving for Tomorrow Scholarship' can cover up to full tuition and fees for eligible Missouri residents with financial need. The average percent of need met for all undergraduates is 75%. Average need-based aid refers to scholarships and grants. Average merit aid refers to non-need-based aid, which typically includes merit scholarships.

scholarships.name: Chancellor's Scholarship
scholarships.benefits: Highly competitive, for Missouri residents with exceptional academic achievements.

scholarships.name: Distinguished Scholars Award
scholarships.benefits: Most prestigious academic scholarship for non-Missouri residents.

scholarships.name: National Merit Scholarship
scholarships.amount: $20,200 first year ($12,000 for three additional years)
scholarships.benefits: Covers tuition & fees, housing (one-time $7,000), and tech/books (one-time $1,200). For National Merit Semifinalists.
scholarships.application_method: Designate Missouri S&T as first-choice institution

scholarships.name: Kummer Vanguard Scholars Program
scholarships.deadline: Automatic Consideration (or separate application for some aspects)
scholarships.benefits: For STEM majors; includes leadership, research, and innovation opportunities. Renewable for up to 4 years.

scholarships.name: Provost's International Merit Scholarship (Undergraduate)
scholarships.benefits: For high-achieving international first-time freshmen and transfer students.

scholarships.name: Missouri Groundbreaker Scholarship Package
scholarships.benefits: For Missouri residents based on GPA and test scores. Renewable with 3.0 cumulative GPA.

scholarships.name: Out-of-State Groundbreaker Scholarship Package
scholarships.benefits: For non-Missouri residents based on GPA and test scores. Renewable with 3.0 cumulative GPA.

ap_policy.general_rule: Missouri S&T accepts AP exam scores, typically 3 or higher (some specific courses require a 4 or 5). Credit is awarded for specific equivalent courses listed in their registrar's office documentation. Official score reports must be sent directly to Missouri S&T from College Board. A maximum of 30 hours of credit may be awarded for AP, IB, CLEP, and/or Military credit combined.

ib_policy.general_rule: Missouri S&T accepts IB exam scores, typically 4 or higher for Higher Level (HL) exams, with some Standard Level (SL) exams also accepted with high scores. Credit is awarded for specific equivalent courses as outlined by the registrar. Official score reports must be sent directly to Missouri S&T from IBO. A maximum of 30 hours of credit may be awarded for AP, IB, CLEP, and/or Military credit combined.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Missouri S&T accepts academic credit completed at other regionally accredited institutions if the courses are equivalent to coursework offered at Missouri S&T and if a grade of 'C' or better was earned. A maximum of 60 semester hours may be transferred from a two-year institution, and a maximum of 90 semester hours may be transferred toward a baccalaureate degree from four-year institutions. Only credit hours are transferred, not grades. Official transcripts must be sent directly to Missouri S&T from previous institutions. Credits from officially recognized foreign institutions may also be considered.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework
Demonstrated interest in STEM through related extracurricular activities
Well-rounded application including a compelling personal statement and strong letters of recommendation
essay_tips: Address the prompt immediately and concisely, avoiding unnecessary meandering.
Show, don't tell: use concrete examples and vivid descriptions to illustrate your experiences and qualities rather than making broad claims.
Avoid clich√©s; strive for uniqueness in your writing to help you stand out.
Connect your experiences and aspirations explicitly to Missouri S&T's values, specific programs, or how you will contribute to their community.
Seek feedback and revise multiple times to ensure clarity, conciseness, and that all aspects of the prompt are fully answered.

insights.insight: Missouri S&T is a moderately selective institution with acceptance rates generally ranging from 72.5% to 84%, indicating that strong academic performance and a well-rounded application are important for admission.
The university boasts a strong reputation in engineering and STEM fields, with a hands-on approach, numerous design teams, and a high research designation from the Carnegie Foundation.

Missouri S&T offers excellent career outcomes, with graduates reporting high starting salaries (average $72,600) and a high likelihood of job placement or graduate school admission due to robust career fairs and strong industry connections.

outcomes.notes: Ranked among the nation's top universities for best salaries and career placement
